discharge_diagnosis: cerebral artery occlusion, unspecified with cerebral infarction

report_text: **institution emergency department patient name: **name[aaa, bbb m] account #: **id-num date of service: **date[mar 02 06] primary care physician: **name[qqq m ppp] history of present illness: chief complaint: intracerebral hemorrhage. i evaluated this patient with the resident physician, dr. **name[ooo nnn]. we discussed the history, physical and plan. i concur with his findings. i also interviewed and examined the patient myself. i reviewed all the pertinent nursing notes as well as predictation resident notes for this patient. i concur with the content. the patient is an intubated sedated, **age[in 70s]-year-old man who comes from an outside facility with the diagnosis of right intraparenchymal hemorrhage in the basal ganglia thalamus region. the patient was intubated and could not give any other history, but prior to being intubated did give the history of weakness on the left side, as well as around 5 o'clock this evening, he was feeding the dogs, fell having a syncopal episode and rolled down a hill to the neighbor for help. the patient at that time did have left arm and left leg weakness and at the outside facility was diagnosed with an intracerebral hemorrhage. because of progressive symptoms and lethargy along with decreased gag reflex, the patient was intubated and brought here for evaluation. the patient did have blood pressure control prior to arrival with dilantin and was given some mannitol and presents here for evaluation. review of systems: could not be obtained. past medical history: past medical history, medications, allergies, social and family history: otherwise as per the resident's note. physical examination: vital signs: temperature 36.6, pulse 68, respirations 14, assisted 4 over the vent. blood pressure 194/111 and mean of 136. in general, the patient was intubated, sedated, but did have movement on the right side spontaneously and did respond to commands on that side. otherwise he was intubated. heent exam: his head is atraumatic and normocephalic. the pupils were equal, 3 to 2 briskly reactive bilaterally were his pupils. extraocular range could not be fully assessed but his cranial nerves were showing no major facial droop at this time. the patient has no other jvd or bruits. chest is clear to auscultation bilaterally. heart is a regular rate and rhythm without murmur, rubs, clicks, or gallops. abdomen is soft, nontender. extremities show left-sided hemiparesis, right-side follows some commands is briskly responsive. otherwise, the patient has no other skin breakdown at this time. ed course: in the ed, the patient was assessed and did have a ct scan from the outside facility that showed a 2 x 3 cm intraparenchymal hemorrhage in the thalamic region. he did, however, have a ct scan at this facility here, that showed expansion and progression of the bleed to involve most of the right hemisphere with interventricular extension. the ph 7.44, paco2 33, pao2 of 466, sodium was 138, glucose 205, white count was 15.6 and 14.2 over 42.0 where his h&h. platelets were 247, inr is 1. he was typed and screened. at this time he will be admitted to the neurosurgical service with stroke consultation. diagnosis(es): intracerebral hemorrhage with extension at this time to the ventricle on the right. the patient was admitted to the icu. total critical care time for this patient was 45 minutes.
